transcript:
﻿Grid trading has become increasingly popular 
amongst cryptocurrency traders in the past years   and many crypto exchanges even offer one click 
solutions to deploy grid trading strategies as,   so to say, “fire and forget” solutions.
However, most traders still end up losing money   with grid trading strategies due to, most 
of the time, not understanding where the   strengths and weaknesses of these strategies 
are, what type of market phases to use them   in and/or using far too much leverage.
On today’s episode of “The Good, the Bad & the   Bitcoin” I want to explain to you the different 
types of grid trading strategies, their strengths   and weaknesses and show you how I personally use 
Grid trading strategies in a process that I call   “continued optimization hedging” to ensure that 
my strategies are always reflecting the market   reality and not just wishful thinking.
Hi, welcome back, good to see you again! 
  If you know already everything about the different 
types of GRID strategies such as “long grid,   short grid, neutral grid and hedging grid” 
feel free to fast forward a bit to the second   part of this video where I talk about my own grid 
strategies, how to set them up and how to monitor   them. Also if you are interested in monitoring 
how my personal strategies are developing,   which exact settings I apply to my GRIDs and 
how I optimize them on a weekly basis I have   created a new Telegram Channel only dedicated 
to this. It is totally free and I think it is   a fun way to learn how to approach GRID 
trading in a more professional way.
  But now let’s start by looking at the 
different types of GRID strategies
  A grid trading strategy is a type of 
trading strategy that aims to profit   from the natural market volatility of 
an asset, for example a cryptocurrency,   by placing buy and sell orders at regular 
intervals above and below a predefined base price.   The "grid" in this context refers to the series 
of levels at which trades are triggered.
  Once the price of the asset you are trading, 
in this example Bitcoin/USDT reaches one of   these lines or GRID points on the chart an order 
is executed. This can be either a long entry,   a short entry, a Take profit, a long and short 
entry at the same time or a mixture of all,   depending on the exact GRID 
strategy you are using.
  The most common forms of grid strategies 
you will encounter are:
  “Long Grids”, that only use long, or buy orders, 
that are placed at the levels below the current   market price that are then exited once grid lines 
above the current price are reached. 
  A short grid does the same thing as a long grid 
but naturally is aiming to capitalize on falling   prices, so would typically be something 
you want to use in a bear market.
  So called neutral-grid strategies are designed 
to capitalize on trending, or sideways markets,   where the price fluctuates between price points, 
that are, for example, defined by zones of support   and resistance. Typically here short or sell 
orders are executed when the price rises to the   grid points above the current price and long or 
buy orders are executed when the price falls to   the grid points below the current price. 
As long as the price is oscillating in the   sideways direction you defined with your grid you 
will achieve a clear outperformance versus a “buy   and hold” or “short and hold” strategy.
If we talk about strengths and weaknesses of   these classic GRID strategies we have to note that 
usually these types of GRIDs work very well in   ranging markets, which is something we actually 
have seen a lot in cryptocurrencies. 
  However, once a ranging market changes to a 
trending market, be it an up- or downtrend,   these changes occur often very quick and with very 
high volatility in cryptocurrencies. I mean, we   have just seen that this year with Bitcoin phases 
where the price jumps up by 15 % from Friday   afternoon to Monday morning or even intraday up 
and downs of almost 10 %. If you are then invested   into a classic market neutral grid or even short 
or long grid you will quickly be sitting on large   losses or even have your account liquidated 
if you were trading with high leverage. 
  While there is no 100 % solution to 
this problem that can fully protect   your account from underperforming in high 
performance trending markets there are a   number of things you can do to give yourself 
the chance to still earn a bit of money when   cryptocurrencies are suddenly starting to moon 
to the upside…or crash to the downside.
  Instead of using one of the classic 
grid strategies I am, for example,   using a so-called “Hedge Grid Strategy”.... 
This means that once one of the price points   on my grid is reached a Long and Short order are 
opened at the same time. At first glance this,   of course, does not make sense because these 2 
orders basically cancel each other out… However,   over time, the realized profits that are taken 
by closing one of the positions once a new grid   line is reached should offset unrealized losses. 
Furthermore, in times where the markets start to   trend very much into 1 direction a hedge grid will 
offset some of your losses and not strain your   margin as much as a classic grid strategy.
I the next part of this video I will walk you   through the process on how I set up 2 of 
these Hedge Grid Strategies 9 days ago,   analyze how they have performed until today, 
how to continuously optimize them and how   you can also do this without having to sit in 
front of your screens for hours and hours.
  For this I am using a tool called 
wundertrading.com which allows me to set up,   backtest and optimize GRID bots for the different 
crypto exchanges I am using. If you want to use   this tool as well you will find a link in 
the description of this video and a pinned   comment with a link to the tool which will also 
give you a 10 % discount on their plans.
  First thing you will notice are 2 segments: One is 
called “Popular” where you can find pre-defined,   ready to use bots with their corresponding 
strategy, for example “Hedge Grid” or   “Classic Grid”. In addition you can choose 
from Futures and Spot trading bots. 
  I am concentrating on building a bot 
that trades the future markets for me,   so I click on “advanced”. You can now see 
quite a lot of settings that are available,   allowing you to adjust your personal bot to what 
you like the most. In my case I want to create   a hedge grid on Bitcoin/USDT with a lowest grid 
price of 45,000 USD and a highest Grid price of   88,000 USD. Now I have to select the profit 
or distance between each of the grid lines   and the trade size per grid line. 
You can see here also that when I change   the number of grids from 22 to 50 that 
the profit per grid changes from 3 % to   1.35 %, basically making my bot more active.
One cool thing about wundertrading is that I can   now backtest how my bot would have performed in 
the last 15 days of trading and you can see that   my bot would have earned 76 USD for me. 

  Now, why only 15 days of backtesting? Would 
it not make sense to backtest the strategy on   as much data as possible? Under normal 
circumstances I would always say: yes,   you have to test your trading strategy 
on as much data as possible. However,   as grid trading strategies are very sensitive to 
changes in trend and volatility plus over time   will start to accumulate positions with unrealized 
losses it is, in my opinion, essential to adjust a   grid strategy to new and updated settings at least 
every 2 weeks….even better every 7 days. From my   experience this really is the essential part 
of being successful with grid strategies.
  
One very nice feature of Wundertrading   is the possibility to automatically optimize 
my strategy to what would have been the best   settings for my selected Grid range. This 
basically takes the effort of adapting my   strategy to the latest real market volatility 
off my shoulders and is really overall a very   useful setting. I can then also apply these 
optimized settings with just 1 mouse click. 
  I then just activated the bot 
by clicking on “Create Bot”   to let it start to automatically trade my 
strategy on the exchange I connected. 
  Later that day I, by the way, created another 
bot with 100 Grids instead of 55 to kind of   see how the 2 would differ in performance over 
the course of the next couple of days. 
  One thing you probably have noticed is that I just 
chose an investment of 100 USD per Grid despite   having 10,000 USD on each account. General rule 
of thumb to stay on a more conservative side is to   divide the total amount of money you are using for 
a grid strategy by the number of GRIDs. So, for   example 10,000 USD divided by 100 GRids = 100 USD 
per Grid. This is, of course, if you wish to not   utilize any leverage at all. If you are planning 
on using leverage you can, of course, adjust these   numbers and, for example, use 250, 500 or even 
1,000 USD per Grid in your strategy. However,   be aware that leverage will not just amplify 
your profits but also your losses.
  Now, remember how I told you earlier how classic 
grid trading strategies are very sensitive to   strong trending markets and that I thought that 
using hedge grid strategies is the better way of   trading grids with cryptocurrencies? My theory 
underwent a reality check in the next 9 days   with Bitcoin performing by almost 14 % to the 
upside and quite significant volatility to the   upside and sometimes also the downside. 
After almost exactly 9 days of trading I   re-checked on my 2 strategies to begin the process 
of optimization again and saw that despite having   had such a strong upside volatility in Bitcoin 
in the past 9 days the strategies still managed   to produce some profits. Of course, these profits 
were not jaw dropping if compared to the 10,000   USD I used for each strategy but the mere fact 
that despite market conditions that usually are   deadly for grids my strategies still managed to 
stay in the green numbers showed me that my theory   on the benefits of using hedge grids is working 
quite well. Under normal circumstances with more   sideways ranging markets we probably would have 
seen something between 70 and 120 USD per strategy   in profit, which is, a very good performance 
taking into account the very conservative   settings I had chosen for the strategies.
So, in summary using a hedge grid strategy,   not going too crazy with leverage and optimizing 
plus restarting your grid strategy every 7 to 14   days can, in my opinion, help you to get the best 
out of your own grid trading strategies.
  That brings us to the end of today’s video. 
If you want to know how the performance of my   GRIDs continues and you do not want to wait 
for the next video update on them plus which   settings I am currently using feel free to join 
my Telegram channel dedicated to these strategies.   Also make sure to leave me a like and subscribe 
to my channel….that is the only way the YouTube   algorithm notices small channels like mine.
Until we see each other again: happy investing!
